name: Patreksfjörður - Gateway to Látrabjarg
description: Patreksfjörður is a charming fishing village in Iceland's remote Westfjords region, serving as the largest settlement and service center for the southern Westfjords and, most importantly, as the gateway to Látrabjarg—Europe's largest seabird cliff and one of Iceland's most spectacular natural wonders. This community of approximately 650 residents maintains traditional Westfjords character while providing essential services for both locals and the growing number of visitors exploring this dramatic and least-visited region of Iceland. The village sits at the head of the fjord bearing the same name, surrounded by steep mountains and overlooking the Atlantic Ocean, with an economy traditionally based on fishing and fish processing that is increasingly supplemented by tourism. From Patreksfjörður, the main attraction is undoubtedly Látrabjarg, located approximately 40 kilometers to the west via Route 612, a sometimes-challenging gravel road that leads to one of the most thrilling wildlife viewing experiences in all of Iceland. Látrabjarg is a line of towering bird cliffs stretching 14 kilometers along Iceland's westernmost point, with vertical faces rising up to 441 meters directly from the Atlantic Ocean. These cliffs serve as nesting habitat for millions of seabirds during the breeding season (mid-May through late August), including enormous colonies of Atlantic puffins, razorbills, guillemots, kittiwakes, fulmars, and gannets.
